lines.text: Enter Clown and FABIAN

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: Now, as thou lovest me, let me see his letter.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: Any thing.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Do not desire to see this letter.

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: This is, to give a dog, and in recompense desire my dog again.
Enter DUKE ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and Lords

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Ay, sir we are some of her trappings.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: I know thee well how dost thou, my good fellow

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Truly, sir, the better for my foes and the worse for my friends.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Just the contrary the better for thy friends.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: No, sir, the worse.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: How can that be

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Marry, sir, they praise me and make an ass of me now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass: so that by my foes, sir I profit in the knowledge of myself, and by my friends, I am abused: so that, conclusions to be as kisses, if your four negatives make your two affirmatives why then, the worse for my friends and the better for my foes.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Why, this is excellent.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: By my troth, sir, no though it please you to be one of my friends.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Thou shalt not be the worse for me: theres gold.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: But that it would be doubledealing, sir, I would you could make it another.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: O, you give me ill counsel.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Put your grace in your pocket, sir, for this once, and let your flesh and blood obey it.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Well, I will be so much a sinner, to be a doubledealer: theres another.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Primo, secundo, tertio, is a good play and the old saying is, the third pays for all: the triplex, sir, is a good tripping measure or the bells of Saint Bennet, sir, may put you in mind one, two, three.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: You can fool no more money out of me at this throw: if you will let your lady know I am here to speak with her, and bring her along with you, it may awake my bounty further.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come again. I go, sir but I would not have you to think that my desire of having is the sin of covetousness: but, as you say, sir, let your bounty take a nap, I will awake it anon.
Exit

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me.
Enter ANTONIO and Officers

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: That face of his I do remember well Yet, when I saw it last, it was besmeard As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war: A bawbling vessel was he captain of, For shallow draught and bulk unprizable With which such scathful grapple did he make With the most noble bottom of our fleet, That very envy and the tongue of loss Cried fame and honour on him. Whats the matter

lines.speaker: first officer
lines.text: Orsino, this is that Antonio That took the Phoenix and her fraught from Candy And this is he that did the Tiger board, When your young nephew Titus lost his leg: Here in the streets, desperate of shame and state, In private brabble did we apprehend him.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side But in conclusion put strange speech upon me: I know not what twas but distraction.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Notable pirate! thou saltwater thief! What foolish boldness brought thee to their mercies, Whom thou, in terms so bloody and so dear, Hast made thine enemies

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Orsino, noble sir, Be pleased that I shake off these names you give me: Antonio never yet was thief or pirate, Though I confess, on base and ground enough, Orsinos enemy. A witchcraft drew me hither: That most ingrateful boy there by your side, From the rude seas enraged and foamy mouth Did I redeem a wreck past hope he was: His life I gave him and did thereto add My love, without retention or restraint, All his in dedication for his sake Did I expose myself, pure for his love, Into the danger of this adverse town Drew to defend him when he was beset: Where being apprehended, his false cunning, Not meaning to partake with me in danger, Taught him to face me out of his acquaintance, And grew a twenty years removed thing While one would wink denied me mine own purse, Which I had recommended to his use Not half an hour before.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: How can this be

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: When came he to this town

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Today, my lord and for three months before, No interim, not a minutes vacancy, Both day and night did we keep company.
Enter OLIVIA and Attendants

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Here comes the countess: now heaven walks on earth. But for thee, fellow fellow, thy words are madness: Three months this youth hath tended upon me But more of that anon. Take him aside.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: What would my lord, but that he may not have, Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Madam!

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Gracious Olivia,

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: What do you say, Cesario Good my lord,

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: My lord would speak my duty hushes me.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: If it be aught to the old tune, my lord, It is as fat and fulsome to mine ear As howling after music.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Still so cruel

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Still so constant, lord.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: What, to perverseness you uncivil lady, To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars My soul the faithfullst offerings hath breathed out That eer devotion tenderd! What shall I do

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Even what it please my lord, that shall become him.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Why should I not, had I the heart to do it, Like to the Egyptian thief at point of death, Kill what I lovea savage jealousy That sometimes savours nobly. But hear me this: Since you to nonregardance cast my faith, And that I partly know the instrument That screws me from my true place in your favour, Live you the marblebreasted tyrant still But this your minion, whom I know you love, And whom, by heaven I swear, I tender dearly, Him will I tear out of that cruel eye, Where he sits crowned in his masters spite. Come, boy, with me my thoughts are ripe in mischief: Ill sacrifice the lamb that I do love, To spite a ravens heart within a dove.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: And I, most jocund, apt and willingly, To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Where goes Cesario

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: After him I love More than I love these eyes, more than my life, More, by all mores, than eer I shall love wife. If I do feign, you witnesses above Punish my life for tainting of my love!

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Ay me, detested! how am I beguiled!

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Who does beguile you who does do you wrong

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Hast thou forgot thyself is it so long Call forth the holy father.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Come, away!

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Whither, my lord Cesario, husband, stay.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Husband!

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Ay, husband: can he that deny

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Her husband, sirrah!

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: No, my lord, not I.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear That makes thee strangle thy propriety: Fear not, Cesario take thy fortunes up Be that thou knowst thou art, and then thou art As great as that thou fearst. O, welcome, father! Father, I charge thee, by thy reverence, Here to unfold, though lately we intended To keep in darkness what occasion now Reveals before tis ripe, what thou dost know Hath newly passd between this youth and me.
Enter Priest

lines.speaker: priest
lines.text: A contract of eternal bond of love, Confirmd by mutual joinder of your hands, Attested by the holy close of lips, Strengthend by interchangement of your rings And all the ceremony of this compact Seald in my function, by my testimony: Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my grave I have travelld but two hours.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: O thou dissembling cub! what wilt thou be When time hath sowd a grizzle on thy case Or will not else thy craft so quickly grow, That thine own trip shall be thine overthrow Farewell, and take her but direct thy feet Where thou and I henceforth may never meet.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: My lord, I do protest

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: O, do not swear! Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear.
Enter SIR ANDREW

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: For the love of God, a surgeon! Send one presently to Sir Toby.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Whats the matter

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: He has broke my head across and has given Sir Toby a bloody coxcomb too: for the love of God, your help! I had rather than forty pound I were at home.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Who has done this, Sir Andrew

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: The counts gentleman, one Cesario: we took him for a coward, but hes the very devil incardinate.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: My gentleman, Cesario

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Ods lifelings, here he is! You broke my head for nothing and that that I did, I was set on to dot by Sir Toby.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Why do you speak to me I never hurt you: You drew your sword upon me without cause But I bespoke you fair, and hurt you not.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me: I think you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb. Here comes Sir Toby halting you shall hear more: but if he had not been in drink, he would have tickled you othergates than he did.
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and Clown

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: How now, gentleman! how ist with you

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Thats all one: has hurt me, and theres the end ont. Sot, didst see Dick surgeon, sot

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: O, hes drunk, Sir Toby, an hour agone his eyes were set at eight i the morning.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Then hes a rogue, and a passy measures panyn: I hate a drunken rogue.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Away with him! Who hath made this havoc with them

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Ill help you, Sir Toby, because well be dressed together.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Will you help an asshead and a coxcomb and a knave, a thinfaced knave, a gull!

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Get him to bed, and let his hurt be lookd to.
Exeunt Clown, FABIAN, SIR TOBY BELCH, and SIR ANDREW
Enter SEBASTIAN

lines.speaker: sebastian
lines.text: I am sorry, madam, I have hurt your kinsman: But, had it been the brother of my blood, I must have done no less with wit and safety. You throw a strange regard upon me, and by that I do perceive it hath offended you: Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows We made each other but so late ago.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons, A natural perspective, that is and is not!

lines.speaker: sebastian
lines.text: Antonio, O my dear Antonio! How have the hours rackd and tortured me, Since I have lost thee!

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Sebastian are you

lines.speaker: sebastian
lines.text: Fearst thou that, Antonio

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: How have you made division of yourself An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin Than these two creatures. Which is Sebastian

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Most wonderful!

lines.speaker: sebastian
lines.text: Do I stand there I never had a brother Nor can there be that deity in my nature, Of here and every where. I had a sister, Whom the blind waves and surges have devourd. Of charity, what kin are you to me What countryman what name what parentage

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Of Messaline: Sebastian was my father Such a Sebastian was my brother too, So went he suited to his watery tomb: If spirits can assume both form and suit You come to fright us.

lines.speaker: sebastian
lines.text: A spirit I am indeed But am in that dimension grossly clad Which from the womb I did participate. Were you a woman, as the rest goes even, I should my tears let fall upon your cheek, And say Thricewelcome, drowned Viola!

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: My father had a mole upon his brow.

lines.speaker: sebastian
lines.text: And so had mine.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: And died that day when Viola from her birth Had numberd thirteen years.

lines.speaker: sebastian
lines.text: O, that record is lively in my soul! He finished indeed his mortal act That day that made my sister thirteen years.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: If nothing lets to make us happy both But this my masculine usurpd attire, Do not embrace me till each circumstance Of place, time, fortune, do cohere and jump That I am Viola: which to confirm, Ill bring you to a captain in this town, Where lie my maiden weeds by whose gentle help I was preserved to serve this noble count. All the occurrence of my fortune since Hath been between this lady and this lord.

lines.speaker: sebastian
lines.text: [To OLIVIA]  So comes it, lady, you have been mistook: But nature to her bias drew in that. You would have been contracted to a maid Nor are you therein, by my life, deceived, You are betrothd both to a maid and man.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Be not amazed right noble is his blood. If this be so, as yet the glass seems true, I shall have share in this most happy wreck. Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.
To VIOLA

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: And all those sayings will I overswear And those swearings keep as true in soul As doth that orbed continent the fire That severs day from night.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Give me thy hand And let me see thee in thy womans weeds.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: The captain that did bring me first on shore Hath my maids garments: he upon some action Is now in durance, at Malvolios suit, A gentleman, and follower of my ladys.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: He shall enlarge him: fetch Malvolio hither: And yet, alas, now I remember me, They say, poor gentleman, hes much distract. A most extracting frenzy of mine own From my remembrance clearly banishd his. How does he, sirrah
Reenter Clown with a letter, and FABIAN

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Truly, madam, he holds Belzebub at the stavess end as well as a man in his case may do: has here writ a letter to you I should have givent you today morning, but as a madmans epistles are no gospels, so it skills not much when they are delivered.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Opent, and read it.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers the madman. By the Lord, madam,
Reads

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: How now! art thou mad

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: No, madam, I do but read madness: an your ladyship will have it as it ought to be, you must allow Vox.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Prithee, read i thy right wits.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: So I do, madonna but to read his right wits is to read thus: therefore perpend, my princess, and give ear.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Read it you, sirrah.
To FABIAN

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: [Reads]  By the Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the world shall know it: though you have put me into darkness and given your drunken cousin rule over me, yet have I the benefit of my senses as well as your ladyship. I have your own letter that induced me to the semblance I put on with the which I doubt not but to do myself much right, or you much shame. Think of me as you please. I leave my duty a little unthought of and speak out of my injury. THE MADLYUSED MALVOLIO.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Did he write this

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Ay, madam.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: This savours not much of distraction.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: See him deliverd, Fabian bring him hither. My lord so please you, these things further thought on, To think me as well a sister as a wife, One day shall crown the alliance ont, so please you, Here at my house and at my proper cost.
Exit FABIAN

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Madam, I am most apt to embrace your offer. Your master quits you and for your service done him, So much against the mettle of your sex, So far beneath your soft and tender breeding, And since you calld me master for so long, Here is my hand: you shall from this time be Your masters mistress.
To VIOLA

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: A sister! you are she.
Reenter FABIAN, with MALVOLIO

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Is this the madman

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Ay, my lord, this same. How now, Malvolio!

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Madam, you have done me wrong, Notorious wrong.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Have I, Malvolio no.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Lady, you have. Pray you, peruse that letter. You must not now deny it is your hand: Write from it, if you can, in hand or phrase Or say tis not your seal, nor your invention: You can say none of this: well, grant it then And tell me, in the modesty of honour, Why you have given me such clear lights of favour, Bade me come smiling and crossgarterd to you, To put on yellow stockings and to frown Upon Sir Toby and the lighter people And, acting this in an obedient hope, Why have you sufferd me to be imprisond, Kept in a dark house, visited by the priest, And made the most notorious geck and gull That eer invention playd on tell me why.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing, Though, I confess, much like the character But out of question tis Marias hand. And now I do bethink me, it was she First told me thou wast mad then camest in smiling, And in such forms which here were presupposed Upon thee in the letter. Prithee, be content: This practise hath most shrewdly passd upon thee But when we know the grounds and authors of it, Thou shalt be both the plaintiff and the judge Of thine own cause.

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: Good madam, hear me speak, And let no quarrel nor no brawl to come Taint the condition of this present hour, Which I have wonderd at. In hope it shall not, Most freely I confess, myself and Toby Set this device against Malvolio here, Upon some stubborn and uncourteous parts We had conceived against him: Maria writ The letter at Sir Tobys great importance In recompense whereof he hath married her. How with a sportful malice it was followd, May rather pluck on laughter than revenge If that the injuries be justly weighd That have on both sides passd.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Alas, poor fool, how have they baffled thee!

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Why, some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrown upon them. I was one, sir, in this interlude one Sir Topas, sir but thats all one. By the Lord, fool, I am not mad. But do you remember Madam, why laugh you at such a barren rascal an you smile not, hes gagged: and thus the whirligig of time brings in his revenges.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Ill be revenged on the whole pack of you.
Exit

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: He hath been most notoriously abused.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Pursue him and entreat him to a peace: He hath not told us of the captain yet: When that is known and golden time convents, A solemn combination shall be made Of our dear souls. Meantime, sweet sister, We will not part from hence. Cesario, come For so you shall be, while you are a man But when in other habits you are seen, Orsinos mistress and his fancys queen.
Exeunt all, except Clown

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: [Sings] When that I was and a little tiny boy, With hey, ho, the wind and the rain, A foolish thing was but a toy, For the rain it raineth every day. But when I came to mans estate, With hey, ho,  and c. Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate, For the rain,  and c. But when I came, alas! to wive, With hey, ho,  and c. By swaggering could I never thrive, For the rain,  and c. But when I came unto my beds, With hey, ho,  and c. With tosspots still had drunken heads, For the rain,  and c. A great while ago the world begun, With hey, ho,  and c. But thats all one, our play is done, And well strive to please you every day.
Exit
